proof:
We begin by partitioning the vertex set $V$. Let $P$ be the set of vertices with degree no greater than $b$, so $P := \{v \in V : \text{deg}(v) \le b\}$. We then define $Q$ as the set of all other vertices, $Q := V \setminus P$. This constitutes a partition, as each vertex is in precisely one of $P$ or $Q$.

First, we will prove the bound concerning the subgraph induced by $P$, denoted $G[P]$. By the definition of $P$, for any vertex $v \in P$, its degree in the graph $G$ is $\text{deg}(v) \le b$. Because $G[P]$ is a subgraph of $G$, the degree of any vertex $v$ in $G[P]$ cannot exceed its degree in $G$. Thus, $\text{deg}(v) \le b$ in $G[P]$ as well. From this, it follows that the maximum degree of the induced subgraph is $\Delta(G[P]) \le b$.

Now, we will establish the bound on the size of $Q$. It is a fundamental property of graphs that the number of edges is half the sum of the degrees of the vertices. This leads to the following chain of relations:
$$ m = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in V} \text{deg}(v) \ge \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in V \setminus P} \text{deg}(v) > \frac{1}{2} \sum_{v \in Q} b = \frac{1}{2} |Q| \cdot b. $$
By rearranging this inequality, we obtain the result $|Q| < \frac{2m}{b}$.
